full_threads.body:
Helping SEOs keep up, stay sharp, and occasionally scream into a pillow

Yeah, That WasSERP #1


Good morning, human, and welcome to Yeah, THAT'S WASSERP, your new favorite excuse to pretend you're "checking industry updates" while avoiding client emails. This is our first ever issue, and we're kicking things off strong.


Stack Overflow is finally being honest about why it's losing half its traffic. Google's core update is still chewing through SERPs. And yes, emojis might be back in snippets. Again. Welcome to another week in the search trenches.


Stack Overflow Lost 50% of Its Traffic. They Just Told Us Why.


Last week, Stack Overflow published a rare bit of clarity in tech PR. In A New Era of Stack Overflow, they addressed the elephant in the SERP:

Yes, their traffic has plummeted. And no, it's not all AI's fault.


What they admitted:

  • The platform got bloated, cold, and unwelcoming.
  • Moderation became overly strict and alienating.
  • They stopped listening to the community that built it.


What they're doing now:

  • Launching OverflowAI to surface better answers, faster.
  • Reworking onboarding and contributor UX.
  • Trying to become "helpful" again before AI tools make them irrelevant.


"This isn't a story of AI replacing community. It's a story of what happens when a community is ignored."


Why you should care:


If your site relies on user-generated content, or even just reader trust, treat this as a stark (no pun intended) warning. SEO didn't (nearly) kill Stack Overflow; their culture did.


Of Winners, Losers, and Brutal Truths: Google's June Update Fallout


16 days, 18 hours.


That's how long Google took messing with rankings before finally calling the June Core Update done. The results are total chaos with a serious serving of "what on earth?."


Who got nuked:

  • Pages with intros thinner than a LinkedIn post
  • Blogs force-feeding keywords like it's 2019
  • "Ultimate guides" written by interns who once googled the topic
  • Affiliate sites recycling the same boring CTA in 80 different listicles

Who thrived:

  • Pages that didn't treat Google like it was born yesterday
  • Content with actual first-hand experience, real expertise, and zero fluff
  • Sites that remembered readers are not bots


Brutal Truth:Google is over and done with bloat. If your content is long and wrong, you're just opening the door to grateful competitors.


Emojis Are Back in SERP Snippets (Maybe?)


Some users are spotting emojis in titles and meta descriptions on Google and Bing. Is it a bug? A test? A cry for help?


We don't know. Google's not talking. But here's what's showing up:

  • 🔥 for trending queries
  • 🤖 for AI-related results
  • Random emojis pulled from page titles


Should you start using emojis in your SEO titles?

Not unless you want to confuse Google and your boss.


What We're Reading


"A New Era of Stack Overflow" - Stack Overflow Blog

Brutally honest breakdown of what went wrong and how they're trying to fix it. Worth your 5 minutes.

Read →


"Google June 2025 Core Update Finished Rolling Out" - SERoundtable

Some sites are bouncing back from March damage, just in time for new volatility.

Read →


"AIO, GEO...What Do They Mean (and Why Do They Suddenly Matter)? - NOBS Marketplace Blog

That's a lot of acronyms-all of which decided to pop out like daisies just last month.

Read →


Buzzwords You'll Keep Hearing (Whether You Like It or Not)


AIO (AI Optimization)

Content made for how AI reads, ranks, and summarizes, especially in SGE and ChatGPT. Optimized headings, fast clarity, no fluff.


GEO (Generative Engine Optimization)

You're not just fighting for Google's #1 spot anymore. You're optimizing to be quoted inside AI chatbots.


SGE (Search Generative Experience)

Google's AI overview box that cannibalizes your organic CTR and sometimes forgets to cite you. Still in testing, just as terrifying.


EEAT (Experience, Expertise, Authoritativeness, Trustworthiness)

Still the north star. Still not a ranking factor. Still confusing clients.


Trivia Time

How do you know it's a Google update week?


A) X (formerly Twitter) is on fire

B) Your GA chart flatlined

C) Clients suddenly remember your number

D) All of the above


Until Next Time


Watch your traffic. Avoid SERP-induced panic. And for the love of rankings, stop saying "just sprinkle in some keywords."


See you in the SERPs,


Team WasSERP at NOBS Marketplace
NO-BS Marketplace

131 Continental Drive, Suite 305
19713 Newark, Delaware
